resources.string: The appendix is a thin tube attached near the meeting point of the small and large intestine. Its function is still under study but it is not necessary to health.
A brain is the control center of the body. It controls the body’s movements and activities. It is also the center of thought, memory, and feelings.
The clavicle, also called the collarbone, is a bone that connects the sternum to the shoulder. It is one of the most common bones to break.
The distal radius is the end part of the arm bones that are connected to the wrist. Fractures to this area are very common.
The gallbladder is a sac that takes bile made in the liver and stores it. The bile is released to the small intestines to help digest food.
The kidneys are a pair of organs that remove waste from the body by filtering the blood. The waste gets turned into urine and sent down to the bladder.
The liver is an organ that filters the blood that comes from the digestive track. It breaks down the toxins from chemicals and drugs. It also makes important proteins the body needs.
The lungs are two organs in the chest that help you breathe. They take in the oxygen sent to them and spread it throughout the blood.
The spleen is an organ near the stomach. It recycles old blood cells, stores white blood cells, and filters the blood.
Tonsils are the two balls of tissue at the back of the throat. They can stop bacteria and viruses from entering the body and create white blood cells to fight them.
Diathermy is an electrosurgical tool, meaning it needs electricity to do its job. It creates heat using electricity, and on certain settings can be used to relax muscles.
Diathermy is used in physical therapy and in surgery. It can be used to cut into parts of your body that are making you sick, or to stop blood vessels from bleeding.
Forceps are a metallic instrument with a hinge, able to grasp and hold objects. They are more precise than fingers, and are often used when a doctor needs his or her hands free for other tasks.

During surgery, forceps are used to grasp tissue in your body so that doctors can get to the areas that are making you sick and fix them. They are designed to securely hold tissue so that they do not hurt you.
Retractors are a metallic tool with an angled blade. Once the instrument is in place, it maintains the position desired by the surgeon. They can be handheld or perched on the end of a robotic arm.
While forceps are used to pull back tissue, retractors are used to hold tissue in place, making it easier for surgeons to see and access the places they need to work on.
Suction Tube devices are either mechanical hand pumps or electrical/battery-powered mechanisms connected to plastic tubing with a rigid tip, the Yankauer suction tip.
Suction tubes are used by surgeons to remove harmful stuff from your body during surgery, or to remove stuff that makes it hard for surgeons to see to do their work.

Sutures are like thread. In the same way thread holds your clothes together, sutures hold your skin together after doctors have fixed what\'s making you sick. Some even dissolve on their own, without having to be removed.

Sutures are generally applied with a needle, and the choice of which sutures to use can be complex. Depending on the tissue being held together and the forces applied by the wound, surgeons must choose sutures of proper strength and elasticity.

Defibrillators are tools you have probably seen used on TV, and they were probably used incorrectly in those portrayals. They are electric paddles used to restore the normal rhythm of your heart, not to restart the heart after cardiac arrest, as is often shown.

It is very unlikely that you will ever need to have this tool used on you, but it is important to know it is there just in case! In the image above, you can see the woman making a point of avoiding contact with the man being defibrillated. This is also why they yell \"Clear!\" on TV: so that the electrical current doesn\'t go where it\'s not supposed to.

Anesthesia machines use a measured, steady supply of medical gases to ensure your surgery is completely painless. These advanced machines track all of your vital signs so that you get the correct amount of gas.

Prior to surgery, your doctor will place a plastic mask over your nose and mouth, and then tell you to count backwards from 10. You probably won\'t get far past number 7, because your body will have absorbed the gases through your lungs, and you will be deep, deep asleep! When you wake up, the surgery will be over, and you will be better!
Stethoscopes are probably the most famous medical device, seen in many cartoons and movies. These devices allow doctors to listen to your heart, lungs, and even sounds in your stomach!

Like the Sphygmomanometer (the blood pressure cuff), these devices are quite common and part of your regular check-up during your doctor visit, and will also likely be used before surgery to avoid complications. Aside from possibly cold metal against your skin, there is nothing to worry about!

If attempting to pronounce this word intimidates you, don\'t worry, you\'re not alone. This device checks your blood pressure using an inflated cuff and mercury. The result will be 2 numbers like: xx/yy. The left number describes your heart\'s contraction pressure; the right, its relaxation pressure.

This tool is so common, you will likely see it during every regular office visit. It is part of your doctor\'s basic toolkit for keeping you healthy. It is also used immediately before surgery to make sure there will be no complications. You will feel a squeeze from the cuff, a pause, then it will relax and it is done.

Pen Torches, as their name implies, look like pens, but are equipped with a powerful flashlight. Your doctor uses these devices to check the pupillary response from your eyes, and also to check your nose and mouth, to make sure you are healthy.

Along with the Stethoscope and the Sphygmomanometer (the blood pressure cuff), this device is among the most common in your doctor\'s tool belt. Expect to see it during regular office visits and check-ups, and to have your doctor ask you to follow his finger with your eyes as the light peers into your pupils, ensuring the health of your eyes.

X-ray Machines are devices with a generator which holds a vacuum tube, directing a stream of electrons which are collected by another device to form images of your internal body. 99% of the energy used is released as heat, and only 1% goes towards the X-rays!

You have probably encountered X-ray machines before, at the dentist. You will stand or lie on a table and have a cover placed over you to prevent excess radiation (small amounts do not hurt!). The technician will then move back so as be out of range, and then the internal image is taken. It is not so different from having your picture taken.

CT stands for Computed Tomography. They are often pronounced as \"cat\" scans. These devices make use of a rotating X-ray tube and a series of detectors. Like regular X-rays, they show doctors the inside of your body.

CT Scans can seem intimidating, but are quick and easy. You lie down on a table which moves you partially inside the circular machine so that it can take internal images. You need to remain still so that the scan is done properly, and the technician will make sure you do not have metal on you that can interfere with the results.

MRI stands for Magnetic Resonance Imaging. It looks very similar to a CT Scan Machine, but the way it works is different. MRI Machines use magnetic fields instead of the X-rays used in CT Scans. Like X-rays and CT Scans, MRIs produce images of your internal body.

MRIs function much like CT Scans. You lie down on a table and are moved partially inside the MRI machine so that internal images of your body can be taken. For the scan to take the correct images, you need to remain still, and the technician will make certain you don\'t have metal objects on you that can interfere with the results.

IV stands for Intravenous Therapy. Consisting of a needle, plastic tubing, and a bag of fluids, it gives you necessary medication and nutrients directly into your veins to keep your body healthy when you can\'t take them by mouth, such as during surgery.

No one likes needles, but the ones used in IVs are very small. A nurse will swab your arm with alcohol to kill bacteria, then insert the needle with the plastic tubing attached. You will feel only a small prick since nurses are practiced at finding a vein and quickly inserting. It will then be taped to keep it in place.
A spirometer is a relatively small, plastic device with either a floating ball or a piston encased inside and a flexible, plastic tube for you to breathe into. It measures your lung function.

Spirometers are used to help keep your lungs healthy. You simply sit up, hold the device, place the mouthpiece in your mouth, and then exhale normally and inhale slowly. Taking these repeated, measured breaths strengthens your lungs over time.
The phrase \"Laparoscopic Surgery\" takes its name from this device. It is a long, narrow, fiberoptic tool that resembles a tube with a very small camera on the end.

During surgery, this medical device is used to make the procedure as minimally invasive as possible. Surgeons don\'t have to made such a wide opening to see what they are doing since the camera sees for them. This also reduces scarring.

A Patient Monitor is an electronic medical device. It measures your vital signs (such as heart rate, oxygen level, blood pressure, etc.) and displays the data on its screen so doctors can make sure you\'re doing ok.

You may encounter a smaller, simpler monitor in your doctor\s office, but the ones present in hospital rooms and surgical theaters are much more advanced. They are using during surgery and, afterwards, during recovery, enabling doctors to keep you healthy and safe.

A C-Arm Machine is a mobile medical imaging device commonly used in operating rooms and based on X-ray technology. The name is derived from its shape, which resembles a C, with the X-ray source at one tip and the X-ray detector at the other tip.

During use, you will lie on a table while the mobile device is placed over and under you, so that you are in the center of the C. As with other X-ray techniques, you will need to remain still for an accurate image to be taken.

A Nebulizer is a small machine that converts liquid medicine to mist, so that it is easier for you to absorb using your lungs. They have an air compressor, a container for medicine, and a connecting tube.

If you have asthma, bronchiectasis, or other lung problems, Nebulizers help relieve your symptoms. You simply use a mask or mouthpiece to inhale the mist, taking slow, deep breaths, for about 10 to 15 minutes.

A Ventilator is a medical device that moves air in and out of your lungs using mechanical ventilation. They are generally controlled by a computer, although there are simpler ones in use. An air/oxygen mixture is compressed, pushing it into your lungs until pressure is reduced and your lungs passively exhale.

Ventilators are used to provide support to your breathing during surgery, after receiving general anesthesia (when doctors put you to sleep until the surgery is over). A breathing tube is inserted through your mouth and into your airway, then the Ventilator provides oxygenated air.
A Pulse Oximeter is a block-shaped electronic device, rounded on one end, that covers your finger. It measures both your heart rate and the oxygen saturation in your blood.

It is likely that you have encountered this device before. It is used not only in hospitals but in doctors\' offices, as well. A nurse or technician will simply place it over your fingertip, giving near-instant readings, which they will then record to keep tabs on your heart and lung function.

The appendix is a small pouch on the bottom right side of your belly. It is attached to your large intestine.\nSometimes it can become blocked from mucus being trapped inside. This is bad because it can cause bacteria to grow and create infection and inflammation. If not taken out it, it can also burst and the infection can spread to the belly. \nTo stop this from happening, a surgery needs to be done to remove the appendix.

You will go to sleep. The doctors will make few small cuts on your stomach. They will find your appendix and slowly remove it. \nThen they will close your stomach with a few small stitches. Once they are done, you will wake up from your sleep.

Sometimes the gallbladder can form small harmful stones, known as gallstones, inside the bladder.\nThis is dangerous because gallstones can block digestive fluids from exiting the bladder. This can cause a lot of pain and infection if left untreated.\nTo cure this, a surgery is needed to remove the gallbladder.

You will go to sleep. The doctor will make some small cuts on your stomach. The doctor may put a small camera inside your belly and look for your gallbladder.\nUsing some special tool, the doctor will remove the gallbladder. Once the doctor is done, you will wake up from your sleep.

Choledochal cyst is a problem that occurs in the tubes connecting from the liver to the gallbladder. Sometimes this tube can get bigger than normal and cause liver problems. This is bad because it can mess up or block the flow of important fluids from the liver to the small intestine. This can cause the tube to swell and get infected.\nIf surgery is not done to remove the cyst, the liver can get damaged and not work well.

You will go to sleep. The doctor will make small cuts near your belly button. They may put a camera inside to see your organs inside. The doctor puts some gas in your belly so they can see your organs better. Then they will use some special tools to remove the cyst from the tube. The doctor will re-build the tube by using a small section of the intestine. Now everything will be good and the doctor will close your belly and you will wake up.

Sometimes a fibrous tissue can form on the lung, chest wall or the diaphragm which is not normal. There is a small space between the lungs and the chest containing a thin layer of fluid. It\'s important for this area to be moist and free so the lung can expand and deflate normally when you breathe. If this area gets blocked with tissue, then it becomes hard for the lung to expand and deflate normally which can create breathing problems. With surgery, the lungs can be saved.

You will go to sleep. The doctor will put a breathing tube inside your throat and connect it to a machine that helps you breathe. They will make a few small cuts on your chest. The doctor will look inside and take the air out of your lungs. The doctor will move the lungs to the side and find the affected area. They will put a small camera to see the area better. Next the doctor will peel off the bad tissue and put air back into your lungs. The doctor will close your chest and you will wake up.

This surgical procedure is used to treat achalasia. This problem occurs when the nerves in the esophagus become damaged. This can cause the esophagus to become paralyzed or become larger if not treated by a doctor. If this happens, it will become difficult for the esophagus to squeeze down food when you eat and it will become harder for you to swallow food.

You will go to sleep. The doctor will make some small cuts near your upper chest and put some special tools inside. The doctor will cut the LES muscle, which is a muscle at the bottom of your esophagus which connects into the stomach. This muscle gets tights and blocks food from entering your stomach. Once this is cut, the doctor will be all done. They will close your cuts with a few stitches and you will wake up.
You will often share a hospital room with someone else, but separated by a curtain to maintain privacy. Be sure to be respectful to your roommates.
You may see a monitor displaying an electrocardiogram. They record the heart\'s electrical signals. This allows the doctor to monitor the health of your heart.

Single Use Devices are medical equipment that are only used once before thrown away. This is to prevent the spread of any germs or diseases. Some of these items may include syringes, gloves, masks, and bandages.
Standard hospital beds are very comfortable. You can change the height of the head and footrest. Some also have special features like controlling the TV!
An otoscope is a device that shines a light into your ear. This helps the doctor see and check the condition of your ear canal.
An opthalmoscope is a device that shines a light into your eye. The doctor will use it to check the structure and health of your eye.
A blood pressure monitor is used to see how much pressure is in your arteries. This helps the doctor to see how healthy your heart is.
The heart pumps blood that travels all over the body. This helps the body get the oxygen and nutrients it needs.
The small intestine is a long coiled tube in your digestive system. It absorbs the nutrients from the food that passes through.
The large intestine gets waste from the small intestine. It absorbs the water from the waste. This creates stool, which is the waste ready to exit your body.
Automatically download attachments for incoming emails
Only download attachments when manually requested
Food enters the stomach to be digested. The food breaks down physically when the stomach squeezes the food. It also breaks down chemically by acids and enzymes.
The pancreas makes enzymes that are used in breaking down foods. It also makes important hormones like insulin and glucagon.
The spine is made of many bones called the vertebrae. They protect the spinal cord and provide structural support for the body.
How to comfort your child before their surgery and ease any fears
The Day of Your Child\'s Surgery
Knowing what to expect on the day of your child’s surgery can help ease anxiety
Recovery after surgery can be challenging, knowing what to expect can help you help your child cope
Learn how to comfort and care for you child regarding any pain after surgery
